posts.name: Eli Milholland
posts.cooked: I’ve already constructed a mini turret that we showcased in our competitions at two district events. Unfortunately, we didn’t have time to compete at the state or world level. Now, I’m looking to improve this project further and would appreciate advice on a few key aspects: how to effectively operate it, optimal torque and RPM settings, and the ideal degree of rotation. We are currently targeting approximately 6000 RPM with around 270 degrees of rotation, aiming for consistent three-point shooting accuracy at a 95-100% success rate.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: "And you’ve already checked on 2012 robots for ideas, I assume? If you weren’t aware, 2012 was associated with basketball. 2022 may also provide some inspiration."

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked: Depending on the motor, a 6000 RPM speed is likely too high, which could result in insufficient torque.

posts.name: Miles.D
posts.cooked: We have never made a turret for basketballs but we did make a catapult for the Pelicans, our local NBA team. This is the only picture, but it was a piston that shot upward when we hit a button and made it into a goal every time. Unfortunately, it has now fallen into disrepair.

There was a small competition a few years ago called Bot Shot, sponsored by Land O’Lakes, that involved basketball shooting robots. Only one robot had a turret, as far as I remember, from UMN Robotics. This is their reveal video. Some of the folks who worked on this bot might still be on CD, possibly still working in robotics. There’s likely more information available if you look for it.

posts.name: Miles.D
posts.cooked:
The 2022 ball is very similar to the size of a standard basketball, so I would recommend watching some behind-the-bumper footage from 2022. Additionally, 2012 footage would also be great to review.

1: How to drive it
swerve baby!!! Just kidding; your best bet is likely a tank with air tires to allow driving in various places. I've encountered many outreach environments with main-season robots, and I can say that swerve tends to leave noticeable tread marks, which people generally dislike.

We're considering around 6000 RPM and 270 degrees of rotation.
If I'm correct, 270 degrees was standard in 2022 (at least that's what we had).

We aim for consistent 95-100% makes on a 3-point shot from a basketball hoop.
This might be challenging, but it's achievable. One potential solution is using an April tag placed at the same height and a few inches forward from the goal. This setup likely requires something similar.

However, if you bring your own hoop to different locations, mounting an April tag directly to the goal shouldn't be a significant issue.

If you lack the budget for a Limelight or can't obtain one, consider Photon Vision. It's a bit more involved but still reliable.

In conclusion,
This is a fantastic idea, and I think it would be awesome if you guys can get it fully functional! (As just a programmer, I wish I could offer more mechanical advice, but I can't.)

posts.name: Eli Milholland
posts.cooked: We were planning to run a kraken max-sweep as an off-season project (slapping the target when we have that). We had already installed two photon vision cameras during last year's off-season and plan to use them this year as well. I might look into getting a portable hoop as well.

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked: I was one of those students! Not a turret, but a hooded shooter, yes. I'm happy to answer any questions about it. A quick note: You need a LOT of power to shoot a real, full basketball. They are way way heavier than typical FRC game pieces.

The discussion about the power aspect and the equipment used is clear, but the second paragraph needs some adjustments for proper grammar and flow. Here's a cleaned-up version:

"I agree on the lot of power aspect. We used 4 redline motors on our shooter for that competition. Another important factor is the inflation level of the ball. A few psi differences can significantly affect how far the basketball is launched. In 2022, this wasn't as noticeable because the goal was only 4 feet wide. However, when aiming for a standard basketball hoop, even a 1-inch variance in the ball's size can make a big difference."

posts.name: Travis
posts.cooked: The team has decided to use court-safe wheels, specifically pneumatic ones, as part of their new design. This choice ensures that the robot won't damage the basketball court. The swerve robot, which has made around eight appearances, may have accidentally scuffed the NBA court during one of these demonstrations. As a result, it might have been banned from playing on the court and was forced to perform subsequent demonstrations from the sidelines. Their summer project involves building a dedicated basketball bot equipped with a turret that automatically tracks the basket. They are considering using foam basketballs for this project, which would allow the bot to practice catching passes from humans. One potential option they are exploring is the "Silent Hoops Basketball," which is a 29.5-inch foam ball with some bounce, having a diameter of 9.4 inches.

posts.name: Eli Milholland
posts.cooked: The basketball hoop is surprisingly big, but hopefully, the basketballs don't lose too much psi.

posts.name: Miles.D
posts.cooked: What tools did you guys use in order to aim for the goal?
There were strips of reflective tape placed on the backboard of the hoop.

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked:
moved the HTML tags and cleaned up the text. The meaning has been preserved while making it grammatically correct and properly punctuated. ``` The user provided a specific task: they wanted me to clean up some text by removing HTML tags and unnecessary elements. They emphasized preserving the original meaning, formatting with proper grammar and punctuation, and keeping it as a single paragraph without line breaks. Also, they wanted minimal changes for coherence. Looking at the input, it's an HTML snippet from a forum or similar site. There are tags like `
`, ``, `
`, etc. My goal was to strip these out and rephrase the content appropriately. I started by identifying the main elements: the username "NYtoWI", the post number, topic, and the actual message about reflective tape. The blockquote contained only the term "strips of reflective tape," so that needed to be incorporated into the surrounding text smoothly. Next, I focused on the explanation part. The user wrote, "Yep, which explains the bright green ring light around a camera at the top of the shooter." I checked if this made sense in context with the quoted term. It seems to connect the strips of reflective tape to the camera's light ring, possibly indicating a relationship between the two. I then considered how to combine these into one coherent sentence without losing clarity. Ensuring that the sentence flows naturally and maintains proper grammar was key. I also made sure to use appropriate punctuation, such as a comma after "Yep." Finally, I reviewed the cleaned-up version to ensure all HTML tags were removed, the text was concise, and the meaning remained intact. No major changes were necessary beyond structural adjustments to meet the user's requirements. ```

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked:
A lot and a lot. We had some very significant (SCARY!!!) flywheels. You can hear them throughout our reveal, and that’s with the volume turned way down. Everyone working on it had earplugs for test sessions. I wouldn’t necessarily recommend it, but if you go this route, please be very careful and get a mentor to review it for safety. It is important that your flywheels are well-balanced and best if you can put a cage around them on the robot.

To hit from 3pt range, you will need the basketball to be going at least ~35 ft/s, which means the linear speed of your shooting wheel needs to be similar (and not lose energy during the shot, which is why we had big flywheels). The RPM depends on the size of your shooting wheel.

I will also note something that we wished we changed - You should have a second wheel/roller at the top of the hood. We were wasting a lot of energy into putting an absurd amount of backspin onto the ball. You want some, probably, but not as much as you get if you have a single wheel powerful enough to shoot 3 point shots.

This is a detailed explanation about flywheels and their role in shooting a basketball.

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked: If I were building one today, I would prefer an AprilTag on the backboard. If you have to set up quickly, maybe you could make a small mounting jig that could interface with the back of the hoop.

posts.name: Sahil Kahn
posts.cooked:
270° of travel is a reasonable number. I know that many teams in 2022 had around that much travel. Depending on your desires, you could explore doing more travel on a turret, so having to "unwrap" the turret is less common. Teams like 2910 and 254 had roughly 720° of travel on their turrets in 2024, which made them better at a role that required them to turn the robot a lot when intaking.

I hope you're referring to the flywheel speed and not the final reduction on the turret, because 6000 RPM is an extremely high number for turret rotation. At that speed, you're looking at a full 270° sweep in under 8 milliseconds.

The motor power required to do this, coupled with the absurd speeds and the control loop timing, could easily tear this mechanism apart the first time it tried to run anywhere near full speed.

For some context: tracking a stationary goal while moving laterally at 20 ft/s halfway to the 3pt line only demands about 100°/sec of turret rotation. Even accounting for drivetrain rotation in the opposite direction at 360°/sec, 400–500°/sec (70–80 RPM) is already generous and gives you the headroom needed for fast, responsive aiming.

As for flywheel speeds: you can calculate an appropriate exit velocity based on the distances you want to shoot. Once you have a target exit velocity, you can back-calculate the necessary wheel surface speed. If you're using a passive hood, your shooter wheels will need a surface speed roughly twice your desired exit velocity. Keep in mind that real-world factors like slip and compression losses can reduce your actual exit speed, so it's smart to prototype and validate your numbers, or leave some headroom for tuning.

All of my math is back-of-the-napkin, so I heavily suggest doing your own calculations to find a good speed for your turret given the power and torque available from the motor you will have driving it and your desired tracking speeds, or at the very least, reference the ratios that teams have used in the past. I'd also look at the CAD that teams have published for turrets they have used in the past for inspiration on how to package and power them.
